sentence: A Study of the Relationship Between the Position of a Soccer Player and their Statistics
Introduction

Soccer, otherwise known as football, is a well-known sport that is played all around the world with playability ranging from kicking a ball around to being the main focus of international competitions

Soccer has been focused around many people’s lives whether it be playing the sport or being a super-fan of it, which makes it not only important as a sport but also important as a way of life. In professional leagues, variable statistics are recorded on players to determine how skilled they are and how well they do within a certain league
Professional players aim to raise their football statistics in order to attract the attention of grander teams and therefore get signed and earn more money
This study looks at which factors may play a role into raising a soccer player’s statistics

Specifically, the goal of this report is to use Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) to investigate if the position of a soccer player affects their statistics in terms of playtime, shots attempted, and total passes made
The information in this study may be of use to aspiring soccer players as well as professional players that may not be earning as much as they would like to
Data
Information has been collected on a sample of 595 soccer players
The sample used for this study contains all players that appeared within the 2010 FIFA World Cup
Our main focus will be on the variable Position
Position is a categorical variable that shows the main position for a certain player
The most common position within the sample is Midfielder while the least common position is Goalkeeper
Our research questions will also focus on the three variables of playtime, shots attempted, and total passes
The variable playtime is a quantitative variable that shows the time on the field a certain player got (in minutes)
The variable shots attempted is also a quantitative variable that shows the number of attempts a player shot the ball to the opposing goal
The variable total passes is once again a quantitative variable that shows the total number of passes a player made
Research Scenarios
The Relationship Between a Soccer Player’s Position and their Playtime
Our first question will be to analyze if there is any association or correlation between a soccer player’s position and the amount of playtime they receive within a professional season
To measure this, we will need to conduct an inferential test and we will choose an alpha value of 1%
We hypothesize that there is a relationship between a player’s position and their playtime. To formulate this hypothesis, we will need to focus on the mean playtime for each position
The positions of interest are Goalkeeper, Defender, Midfielder, and Forward

We can see that both Defender and Goalkeeper positions tend to get more playing time than Midfielder and Forward positions
Both Defender and Goalkeeper positions have a median of 270 minutes while the Midfielder position has a median of 167 minutes and the Forward position has the lowest median of 132 minutes
We also see that the minimum for midfielders and defenders is 1 minute, the minimum for forwards is 2, and the minimum for goalkeepers is 45
The maximum for midfielders and goalkeepers is 570 minutes, the maximum for forwards is 564, and the maximum for defenders is 540

The interquartile range for the Goalkeeper position is between 250 and 400, which is well above the ranges for the other positions
The last thing we observe is that there are no outliers when looking at all the data
Overall, this suggests that there is a relationship between playtime and a player’s position
All standard deviations are within a factor of 2, meaning they are so sufficiently close to use ANOVA
Since our assumptions are met, we can perform the test at level 0.01
After performing the ANOVA test, we get a test statistic of F = 15.7301 and a p-value that is approximately 0 (p-value = 0)
Since the p-value of 0 is below the alpha value of 0.01, we reject the null hypothesis

This means that the mean playtime for each position is not equal, and we can conclude that there is sufficient evidence for a relationship between position and playtime. With this conclusion, we also see that the best position for a player in order to have the most playtime is Goalkeeper, followed by Defender, then Midfielder, and then Forward

Discussion/Conclusion
In this study, we examined the relationship between a soccer player’s position and their statistics in terms of their playtime, shots attempted, and total passes
We found that a player’s position is associated with all three variable statistics

We first saw that the best position for playtime is by far Goalkeeper, the best position for shots attempted is Forward followed closely by Midfielder, and the best position for total passes is Defender followed closely by Midfielder
The results of this study further imply that a player’s certain position is associated with certain variable statistics that are more prominent within these positions
It is also important to note that a player’s position does not correlate to these variable statistics, but is only associated with them
A limitation of this study is that the sample may have been biased since it took data from the 2010 World Cup, which includes world-class players but not average professional league players
Another limitation may be that other variable statistics not in the data were not tested, such as goals made
In order for other studies to build on this work, it is important to look at other variable statistics such as goals made to determine if any of them are related to a soccer player’s position
Furthermore, it may be interesting for other studies that may base this work to look at the relationship between certain variable statistics and other sports
